The Meaning of the Three Times in the Nirvana Sutra
Explaining Pure Giving's Doubts
The Treatise Says:

Many disciples have already matured, while Pure Giving has not yet matured. The Buddha, for the sake of Pure Giving who has not yet matured, manifests the great parinirvÄá¹‡a, expounds the great sÅ«tra, receives the great merit, and comes to the city of KuÅ›inagara for the sake of maturing him.
Why does Pure Giving have doubts?
There are two causes and conditions:
First, seeing the common characteristics but not yet seeing the distinct characteristics gives rise to doubt;
Second, seeing the distinct characteristics but not seeing the common characteristics, therefore,

gives rise to doubt. It is like seeing a stump in the distance and doubting whether it is a person or a stump.ğŸ”½If one sees crows gathering on top of it and deer passing under it, one knows it is a stump and not a person;
If one sees someone raising their hand to pick up their clothes, one knows it is a person and not a stump.

Those who do not see the common characteristics and give rise to doubt in the specific characteristics are like space, which has the uncommon characteristic of permanence, and like earth, which has the uncommon characteristic of impermanence.

The Å›rÄvakas have the uncommon characteristics, and doubt arises in the uncommon characteristics of the Å›rÄvakas, whether they are the same as space and permanent, or the same as earth and impermanent.
Ordinary people give rise to doubt because of the common characteristics, while Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas give rise to doubt because of the specific characteristics.
Ordinary people give rise to doubt because of the dharmas that arise, while Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas give rise to doubt because of the dharmas that do not arise.
Cunda does not give rise to doubt because of these two kinds, but gives rise to this doubt in order to benefit sentient beings.
How can such a great bodhisattva give rise to doubt about the Buddha?

In this great assembly, there are many non-Buddhists gathered. Some non-Buddhists say that the Buddha dies and is reborn again, some say that he is like a lamp going out when the oil is exhausted, and some say that after the Buddha's extinction, there is both exhaustion and non-exhaustion.
In order to resolve this doubt, the Buddha spoke a verse:
Originally existent, now non-existent; originally non-existent, now existent; dharmas of the three times,
There is no such thing.
The Buddha spoke this verse for the sake of the two vehicles.
Afflictions are born and attained, and sages attain them through cultivation.
The nature of ordinary beings is born and attained, and the nature of sages is attained through cultivation.
The bonds of afflictions are born and attained, and liberation from bonds is attained through cultivation.
Birth and death are born and attained, and nirvana is attained through cultivation.
What was originally born is now cultivated; what was originally born is now cultivated.
This explanation for the sake of the two vehicles does not slander the Mahayana, but this explanation for the sake of the Mahayana is a slander of the Mahayana.
This is an incompatible Mahayana. Who can make the Mahayana compatible?
Therefore, we rely on the meaning to select and contemplate the meaning, not relying on language and not selecting and contemplating language, and speak for those who practice the Mahayana.

Transcending the three kinds of meanings, it manifests the distinct meaning, saying that what was originally existent now does not exist, what was originally non-existent now exists, and that there is existence in the three times.
These three kinds of meanings do not exist, and do not exist anywhere.
Why are the three kinds of meanings not accomplished?
If what was originally existent now does not exist, then all TathÄgatas and so forth would have no liberation.
Why is it so?
Because the nature does not abide stably, because what existed before does not exist later.
All true existence also does not exist, and true existence and conventional existence also do not exist.
Why is it so?
Because true existence does not differ before and after, and because conventional existence is originally non-existent, therefore the two meanings of true and conventional are not accomplished.

Not clearly understanding these two meanings, the SÄá¹ƒkhya non-Buddhist path also says in this way that the effect exists in the cause, like milk having curds, fresh butter, and so forth, which is the meaning of increasing the SÄá¹ƒkhya and so forth.
If what was originally non-existent, who can create an obstruction in the present time?
If you think that the conditions of obstruction and combination are obstacles, this is not reasonable.
Why is it so?
Because there is no difference between before and after.
If it is not an obstacle now, why was it not an obstacle before?
What logic is there that it was not originally produced from conditions, but later perishes due to conditions?
What is meant by original? What dharma is taken as the basis?
Is it the initial arising or the continuity that is taken as the basis?
If the initial arising is taken as the basis, the initial [arising] is not produced by conditions, and later [it] is also not produced by conditions, just like the initial [arising].
If it is so, the meaning of the suchness of the twelve links of dependent arising is all destroyed, and it is the same as the non-cause theory of non-Buddhists.
If continuity is taken as the basis, continuity is also indefinite.
Why is it so?
Because the parts are indefinite.
How can continuity be the basis?
Therefore, for all dharmas that arise, it is said that there is no cause in the original.
To say this is unreasonable.

As for what was previously nonexistent now exists, if what was previously nonexistent now exists, then there would be no one who attains liberation. If afflictions had not arisen previously, then one would be liberated, but if afflictions arise later, then there would be no liberation.
If what was previously nonexistent now exists, then what is utterly unarisen should be able to arise, like a flower arising in the sky.
If you think that one is without a cause,
this is not so.
Why is it so?
It is like a house and a flower. The two are the same in being previously nonexistent. Why does a house arise from causes and conditions, while a flower does not arise from causes and conditions?
Because they are the same in being nonexistent.
This reasoning is unreasonable.
If what was previously unarisen now arises, then it contradicts the original meaning.
This is not so.
Why is it so?
Because the initial arising is the original.
If you think that the initial arising is not the initial because of causes and conditions, therefore arising is not the original,
this is also not so.
Why is this?
Because you intend to destroy the originally existent and establish the originally existent conditions.
Therefore, it does not go beyond the original, so how can a previously non-existent dharma arise due to conditions?ğŸ”½If it arises, does it arise completely or in parts?
If it arises completely, does it arise simultaneously or sequentially?
If it arises simultaneously, then cause and effect would occur at the same time and be indistinguishable.
If the effect arises after the cause has ceased, what produces the subsequent effect?
It would be like a cooked chicken making a sound and coming back to life.
If it arises completely, what is the use of considering the cause?
If it arises in parts, it also has the same errors as before.
Therefore, the idea that the originally non-existent now exists and that conditions are established is not correct.
The idea that the three times exist is also not correct.
If there are these three times, does the single meaning pervade the three times, or does each individual meaning have three times?
Both of these two meanings are incorrect.
Why is this?
If one meaning pervades the three times, it cannot be said that there are three in one time.
Why is this?
Because they would contradict each other.
If meaning depends on time, then past and future would be infinitely divided.
If time depends on meaning, then because meaning is one, there would be no three times.
Apart from meaning, there is no separate time. Therefore, the three times are all unestablished.
If one thing pervades the three times, that thing cannot be said to have a name.
Why is this?
Because one thing would have two accomplishments. In that case, samsara and nirvana would be one.
If each time has its own, then the three times each have their own. As the present can produce results, why can the past and future not produce?
If it can produce completely, then no one would attain liberation.
If it cannot produce past and future, who ends karmic retribution?
If you say the past and future exist, do you say they exist as substance or as function?
If you say they exist as substance, how can they be divided into three parts?
If you say they exist as function, the past has ceased and the future has not yet arisen, how can they give rise to function?
If you think the three times exist and can speak, the three times cannot speak and the three times cannot speak of substance.
If they have the same substance, one can and two cannot, this is not reasonable.
If you think of time as having the ability to speak but not speaking,
knowing that a plantain bears fruit once and cannot bear fruit again,
the meaning is also unreasonable.
Why is it so?
Because the meaning is indefinite.
Whose possession are these three times?
If they arise from a cause, the difficulty is endless;
if they arise without a cause, then the meaning of time is not accomplished.
If you think of the future as the front, the present as the middle, and the past as the back, and make the three times,
why is it so?
Because the power of the future forces out the present, and the power of the present forces out the past.
It is like the water of the Ganges River, with the water of the future forcing out the water of the present, and the water of the present forcing out the water of the past.
If one time is accomplished, then the three times are accomplished.
This meaning is not so.
Why is it so?
Because the water is simultaneous, but the locations are different.
Therefore, the meaning of the three times and three worlds is not so.
As for there is no place where there is not, as the Hinayana teaches, there is no place, as the non-Buddhists teach, there is no place.
The refutation of the Hinayana and non-Buddhists is like this. The meaning of the verse is to refute wrong meanings and establish correct meanings.
As for refuting wrong meanings, it is based on language.
As for establishing correct meanings, it is based on meaning.
As for the correct meaning, it is originally existent and presently existent, transcending the three times. This is called the correct meaning.

As for originally existent and presently existent, from the initial arousal of the mind until attaining nirvana, it is of one flavor without difference. It does not rely on a cause of birth or a cause of cessation.
If it exists, it is pure. The dharmas of ordinary beings cannot defile it, and the dharmas of sages cannot purify it.
If one commits the four grave offenses or the five heinous crimes, it cannot be diminished. If one cultivates wisdom to eliminate evil, it cannot be increased.

If there are those who attain the pure eye of insight or those who attain the poisonous evil eye of insight, relying on skillful means, they will transcend the path of language and all conceptual thought. The cause and effect that are subsumed are neither a cause nor a result.

This ground cannot be quantified or temporally distinguished. It is the realm of all buddhas and tathÄgatas. Samsara and nirvana are the ground of going against and following. If one goes against it, it is samsara. If one follows it, it is the ground of nirvana.

This is the past, this is the future, this is the ground of mind, this is the ground of mind of vajra after, breaking all views, purifying all views, all sentient beings should enjoy, the TathÄgata's one body, the ultimate place of refuge, embracing all treasures.
This great nirvÄá¹‡a that transcends the three times is for the sake of explaining the merits of nirvÄá¹‡a.
What is it that transcends the three times?
It is because of arising that the three times are distinguished.
Since nirvÄá¹‡a is without arising, it cannot be distinguished.
As for the three times, what has not yet arisen is able to arise, and what has already arisen immediately ceases.
Since nirvÄá¹‡a is without cessation, it abides eternally, and therefore it is sovereign.
Because it is sovereign, it is therefore most blissful.
For the sake of its essence, it is said to be pure, and for the sake of its function, it is said to be eternal, blissful, and self.
Because of its intrinsic nature, it is pure, and because it opposes birth and death, it is eternal, blissful, and self.
Furthermore, there are two kinds of meanings:
If it existed originally and exists now, then it would be a view of permanence;
If it transcends the three times, it is the view of annihilation.
If the two meanings depend on the future, being free from annihilation and permanence is the middle way.
In this way, the characteristics of conventional truth and ultimate truth are mutually dependent, and there is such true dependent origination.
Why is this?
Being free from the two extremes is the true twelve links of dependent origination.
If one can understand this well, one will see the TathÄgata present in the world. Therefore, the TathÄgata says that the twelve links of dependent origination are the body of the TathÄgata.
In the two truths of conventional and ultimate, because they are non-dual, the twelve links of dependent origination are the true Buddha Way.
There are two meanings to this verse:
One is the meaning of countering causes, cutting off wrong paths;
The second is the meaning of attaining principles, revealing the real.
These two meanings are the matters of the TathÄgata, relying on great wisdom and great compassion.
The meaning of the five constants:ğŸ”½First, endless permanence;
Second, unarisen permanence;ğŸ”½Third, eternally present permanence;
Fourth, tranquil permanence;
Fifth, changeless permanence.
The ten kinds of eternal permanence are:
First, permanence due to the boundlessness of causes;
Second, permanence due to the boundlessness of sentient beings;
Third, permanence due to the boundlessness of great compassion;
Fourth, permanence due to the boundlessness of the four bases of supernatural power;
Fifth, permanence due to the boundlessness of wisdom;
Sixth, permanence due to always abiding in concentration;
Seventh, permanence due to being peaceful and cool;
Eighth, permanence due to not being tainted by the eight worldly dharmas while acting in the world;
Ninth, permanence due to the sweetness, tranquility, and freedom from the four demons;
Tenth, permanence due to the unborn nature.
As for the boundlessness of causes, for immeasurable eons one has given up one's body, life, and wealth in order to uphold the true Dharma.
Since the true Dharma is boundless and inexhaustible, this is precisely using boundless causes to attain boundless fruits.
The fruits are precisely the three bodies.
Second, the constant of non-arising, based on the past, is not originally non-existent now, because it is not produced by the mind-born body.
Third, the constant of always being present, based on the future, is free from inconceivable death and destruction.
Fourth, the constant of tranquil abiding, based on the present, is not destroyed by the illness of ignorance and afflictions.
Fifth, the constant of immutability, beyond the three periods of time, is not transformed by the fruits of pure karma.
Third, always being present is free from death;
fourth, tranquil abiding is free from illness;
fifth, immutability is from the first ground to the stage of the TathÄgata, all of which are called endless.
From the eighth ground to the stage of the TathÄgata is called non-arising, and from the ninth ground to the stage of the TathÄgata is also partially attained and called the constant of immutability.
The discussion of the five meanings is all in the stage of the Buddha.ğŸ”½All conditioned things are impermanent,ğŸ”½they are subject to arising and ceasing.
With the cessation of arising and ceasing,
there is peace and bliss.
The Tripiá¹­aka Master's interpretation is as follows:
As for all conditioned things are impermanent, conditioned things refer to the conditioned things of form and mind, which exist in the three time periods.
Impermanence has five meanings of its own:
First, impermanence as loss and destruction;
Second, impermanence as separation of characteristics;
Third, impermanence as transformation, also called impermanence as turning;
Fourth, impermanence as having parts;
Fifth, impermanence as intrinsic nature.
As for what is meant by loss and destruction, it is like the loss and destruction of one's lifespan after a hundred years of life have been used up.
Second, impermanence as separation of characteristics refers to the bones and flesh being scattered and separated.
Third, transformation refers to the initial white color of the bones later changing to the color of a dove.

Turning refers to the transformation of white to the color of a dove.ğŸ”½Fourth, impermanence as having parts refers to the three things of faculties, objects, and consciousness not yet being in union, which is called fundamental non-existence impermanence. Having existed and then returning to non-existence is called destruction, which is having existed and then returning to non-existence.
Impermanence as having parts refers to the faculties, objects, and consciousness coming together in union, which is collectively called having parts.
As for the fifth, intrinsic nature, it is called intrinsic nature impermanence because it possesses the four meanings mentioned above.
That which is born refers to that which will be born in the future.
The dharma of cessation refers to the dharma that has already ceased in the past.
Birth and cessation refers to the present.
As for the present subsuming birth and cessation, it is said that birth and cessation occur in the present because birth immediately ceases.
As for saying that quiescent cessation is bliss, if it is said that the dharma of cessation is bliss, this is not so.
Why is it so?
Because there is cessation in the present that is the past, and the ceased dharma remains, and because of this remainder it is not bliss.
If it is said that the cessation of the present birth and cessation is bliss, this is not so.
Why is it so?
Because there is future birth that remains in the present world, and because of this remainder it is not bliss.
If it is said that future birth is permanent, this is not so, because birth must have cessation and is therefore not permanent.
If one can prevent future dharmas that should arise from arising, then it can be considered happiness.
Tranquility is happiness is precisely this meaning.
